text: Gemini 3 Solves Handwriting Recognition and it‚Äôs a Bitter Lesson Testing shows that Gemini 3 has effectively solved handwriting on English texts, one of the oldest problems in AI, achieving expert human levels of performance. In the autumn of 1968, University of Manitoba Professor R.S. Morgan was optimistic that computers would soon be able to read human text instead of punch cards. "Many humanities scholars are eagerly awaiting the day when they can get their computers to scan a book," he wrote in a new journal called Computers and the Humanities . Hopefully, he said, it would be as simple as shovelling the text "into the maw of the machine", leaving the computer to sort out the technical bits. Morgan was an archaeologist and a computer scientist; as early as 1966, he dreamed of getting computers to read and analyze ancient Minoan hieroglyphs. [1] Morgan was working at the height of the so-called Golden Age of AI when many problems, like computer vision, appeared to have simple solutions. After all, he had just seen the IBM 1287 firsthand and it could read 10 digits and five letters of the alphabet, provided they were written in special boxes on cards. This was proof of concept. "It can read any printed, typewritten or handwritten numbers," h e explained, excitedly , "and it is at this point that we have a glimpse of what humanists are waiting for, an optical reader which will read any font…A machine that combines cheapness" with accuracy. If this transpired, Morgan could see that a whole host of knowledge-work professions would be radically changed. He was a bit early. Sixty years after the launch of the IBM 1287, Gemini 3 Pro has solved handwriting transcription, scoring at levels previously reserved for expert human typists. In our tests, it did so reliably and without hallucinations. As we'll see, the errors it does make are different than those that humans make and are largely centred on fixing punctuation, capitalization, and spelling errors in the original. That this level of accuracy was achieved by a generalist tool like an LLM rather than specialized systems will appear remarkable and surprising to many, but was entirely predictable. As a result, historical work is about

text: To Win on Electricity Prices, Democrats Need Policies That Make Electricity Cheaper Blue states have higher electricity prices than red states. We need more infrastructure - including fossil fuel infrastructure - to ensure that electricity is affordable. Dear readers, One issue that has helped Democrats in this year's elections is public dissatisfaction with electricity prices. Electricity prices in September were 5.1% higher than one year earlier, and the upward march of electricity costs under Donald Trump extends an ongoing trend from the Biden administration. Consumer electricity prices rose by 37.5% from January 2020 to September of this year, outpacing general CPI inflation, which totaled 25.2% over the same period. The cost of piped natural gas has risen even more sharply over that time - 49.3%. Since the start of 2020, consumer prices for electricity and natural gas have significantly outpaced general inflation, while gasoline prices have been volatile and have recently lagged general inflation. (Source: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics via FRED) When you're out of power, inflation is a good issue for you, and Democrats have capitalized on President Trump's failure to actually make life more affordable. But over the long run, Republicans have an advantage on energy as a political issue, because they actually implement policies that make energy cheaper. States run by Republicans tend to have much cheaper electricity than those run by Democrats: while consumers paid a national average of $0.18 per kilowatt hour for electricity in September, the average rate was $0.30 in New England, $0.24 in the Mid-Atlantic, and $0.32 in California . As a party, we should be nervous about the increasing salience of this issue, because we are worse than Republicans at delivering the cheap electricity that consumers want. To gain a long-run advantage on the energy issue, Democrats need to commit to providing energy that is cheap and abundant. That's going to require changing the way we govern, making it easier to produce energy and deliver it to consumers. And it's going to mean scaling back policies that intentionally raise the cost of energy in pursuit of carbon emissions reduction. Consider the situation in Connecticut, which

text: When Volatile Work Schedules Meet SNAP Work Requirements New policies put low income workers in jeopardy of losing vital supports A father of three works at a pizzeria where his schedule resembles a roller coaster: 40 hours one week, 48 hours the next, then plummeting to just eight hours before rising to 24. Under new work requirements for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP, formerly called Food Stamps), the main US program that helps low-income families afford food, a slow month with this erratic scheduling could strip him and his family of vital assistance. That's despite this dad averaging 32 hours of work per week-well above the 80-hour monthly minimum the law will soon require. Subscribe now Proponents of this new policy–a part of July's One Big Beautiful Bill Act that is scheduled to take effect in March 2026–say that this policy will encourage parents to do more to provide for their kids. But the dad working at the pizzeria is not lazy or unwilling to work. In fact, he is doing everything he can to work more hours, taking on extra last-minute shifts when offered. But sometimes his shifts are cancelled or he is sent home early when business is slow. He is one of the parents in a study we have been conducting with over 1,000 service-worker parents, as part of our decade-long research collaboration on the realities of low-wage work and parenting in the 21 st -century United States. His story reveals that today's low-wage work environment is defined by extreme volatility that workers cannot control. The low-wage labor market has fundamentally changed. With the decline of middle-skill jobs and the economic shift away from manufacturing, workers with low levels of formal education- especially parents-are now concentrated in the service sector. Service sector jobs are volatile, with work schedules, like this dad's, fluctuating in response to factors such as foot traffic, weather, local sporting events, and corporate profit targets. These unstable schedules are already hard on parents, worsening mental health and sleep quality . And the new SNAP requirements will am

text: Why collapse is inevitable Part 3) MTI culture as mega-psychopath Part 1 argued that modern humans are maladapted by nature and nurture to the world they themselves have created. Our paleolithic brains are befuddled by the sheer scale, complexity and pace of change of both our socio-cultural and biophysical environments. Part 2 suggested that much of our befuddlement is due to unfamiliar behaviours and circumstances that emerge from the internal machinations of large-scale societal organizations and their interactions with the biophysical systems that contain them. Our Paleolithic brains are not up to the challenge. Socially stable, eco-compatible large-scale societies cannot emerge from these turbulent confrontations. Part 3 makes the case that what does emerge is something else altogether-gross societal malfunction-to-collapse-which may be at least partially explained by pan-cultural ‘psychopathy'. Thanks for reading standstoreeson! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work. Authoritarian repression – social emergence at its violent (almost) worst Photo: Emre Ezer When aberrance becomes the norm Psychopathy is an uncommon but particularly pernicious personality/behavioural disorder. Psychopathic traits include insincerity, egocentrism, the inability to express empathy or remorse and manipulative behaviours including a tendency toward (possibly violent) dominance assertion. Such anti-social behaviour may be masked by smarmy, superficial charm. Psychopathy is pernicious because, despite relative rarity (~1% of the general population), the trait has left a dark, enduring and still-spreading stain on the tapestry of human affairs. Studies show that psychopathic personalities are disproportionately represented -by an order of magnitude-among occupants of head offices in finance and business and at high levels in government, i.e., at centers of wealth creation, prestige and power. text: An anal education. In a previous life, many years ago, I made my bones in a more traditional form of sex education. In a previous life, many years ago, I made my bones in a more traditional form of sex education. From my start as an HIV peer educator during my high school years in Buffalo, through some college volunteer gigs and finally a full-time sex education job with a New York City-based after school program, I did my best to impart accurate, non-judgmental, and supportive messages about sex and sexuality to every from elementary school students to senior citizens. By the standards of America's (admittedly abysmal) sex education programs, the organizations I worked with were cutting edge. We provided honest, fact-based information to our students, we never shied away from words like "condom" and "birth control." When I worked with high school students, the curricula even included lessons on body positivity and consent: clearly, leaps and bounds beyond the "just say no" messaging that many people receive in abstinence-only programs. And yet in spite of how proud I was of the work I was doing, I knew, even at the time, that it was incomplete, even from a health and safety perspective. To be blunt: there was no way that I could educate my students about how to safely engage in anal pleasure - an omission which, let's be real, put certain groups of students at a bigger disadvantage than others. Oh, sure, I could tell them how to use a condom or a dental dam to protect themselves, and that knowledge would suffice regardless of what orifice was in play during their, ahem, play. I could maybe even explain that if you wanted to use a "female" condom internally for anal sex, that you would need to remove the inner ring before inserting it. But anyone who thinks that safe and healthy anal sex* begins and ends with barrier protection is kidding themselves. I couldn't really talk to my students about the importance of lubrication; I certainly couldn't talk to them about the importance of patience and not rushing things and gently opening up the asshole with a finger or toys. I couldn't

text: Murder in Cold Blood The killing of Good is as bad as it gets Credit: Getty Images This is not right. Not justifiable. Not who we are as Americans. Full stop. The act of violence by a federal officer that killed an unarmed American is an unimaginable horror and a national atrocity. Renee Good was murdered by an ICE agent on her way home from dropping off her first grader at school. Video from three different angles shows Good driving onto a street full of protesters and agents near her Minneapolis home. One can then see Good maneuvering her car at the command of several agents. According to eyewitnesses, two agents were yelling at her simultaneously and at cross purposes to turn around, back up, stop, and get out of the car. She rolled down her window to hear and speak with them. Moments before the shooting, she was inching her car forward. An agent, who was standing on the left side of the car, raised his gun and shot Good at point-blank range. A doctor in the crowd offered to help Good. The agent would not let him, saying, "I don't care." Good was a poet and stay-at-home mom who was born and raised in Colorado. She has been described as a devoted Christian who was not politically active, according to her ex-husband's father. Her social media accounts appear to bear this out. Once again, the president and his lackeys are asking Americans not to believe what they see with their own eyes. Rather than console the family or condemn the violence, he orchestrated a fiction to cover up ICE's criminality, abuse of power, and the failures of his draconian deportation policies. Trump claims the ICE agent acted in self-defense and DHS Secretary Kristi Noem called Good a domestic terrorist who weaponized her car to target the agents. While die-hard Trumpsters might gobble that up like it's Thanksgiving dinner, the real story can be seen on the video taken by multiple bystanders. Share ICE stokes fear and heightens tensions rather than de-escalating them. Since Trump took office last January, four people have been killed and five injured

text: The Most Human Part of Space Horror? Redundancies. Real horrors of space start long before the monster arrives. Redundant systems, manual overrides, and ugly industrial design reveal a deeper truth: before we feared aliens, we feared the vacuum. Space horror often promises-well, threatens with the unknowable. Ancient gods sleeping between stars in its impossibly geometric bed. Organisms that don't acknowledge human biology, let alone morality. We expect the terror to arrive from out there . From the void, the alien, the cosmic. Thanks for reading Distracted at the Table! Subscribe for more distractions and obsessions to be published in the future! But before any of that, before the eldritch reveals itself, there is a quieter, more mundane horror that truly defines the genre: Space itself is trying to kill us. That's why everything that humans build beyond Earth is designed to deter, and save our frail bodies from this cold, uncaring emptiness. As a TTRPG player, and a longtime fan of space and sci-fi, I want to explore how this mundane aspect of design and human culture help create stories of terror in fiction. Even with the lack of Alien, this screenshot still tells you how scary this game is. Before the Monster, the Vacuum In most space horror stories, the alien is not the first threat encountered. Oftentimes, we are presented with issues In the TTRPG systems Death in Space & Mothership , the dangers of space are presented as an ever-present threat, despite both systems having each their own "horrors" that are a big part of the game. While in every adventure the monsters change, the hazard of space remains the same. Here's the thing. Unlike the monster, space doesn't hunt us. It doesn't hate us. It doesn't want us dead. It's much worse than that. It simply does not care. Space is not the natural habitat of us humans, but it's so much worse. The vacuum will pull the air out of your lungs without malice. Radiation will scramble the heck out of your cells without intent. Temperature will swing from blistering hit to freezing cold with mechanical indifference. As a gamemaster, I don't get to describe the face of the villain that had killed you, because your character weren't murdered. They were simply dead. W

text: The problem with RFK Jr.'s food pyramid Healthy food is not healthy if it destroys the environment that produces it. Image source: Getty images If a nation's diet requires ecological destruction to sustain it, can it really be called healthy? There was a time when Robert F. Kennedy Jr. would have said no. Before he became the nation's top health official, Kennedy built his career arguing that human health and environmental health were inseparable-that pollution in rivers became pollution in bodies, and that climate change itself was a public health emergency driven by industrial systems. His premise was simple: when the ecosystems that sustain life become unstable, human health becomes unstable too. But in office, Kennedy has begun governing as if health begins and ends inside the human body. Nowhere is that clearer than in the new federal food pyramid his department unveiled this week-an inverted version of the original triangle that encourages beef and dairy consumption on nutritional grounds while ignoring the deeply harmful environmental systems required to produce those foods on an industrial scale. You don't ever need to pay for HEATED-it's free. But if you have the means, paid subscriptions keep us alive and independent. The new inverted food pyramid isn't merely a poster meant to guide individual choices. It is a set of policy guidelines that directs billions of public dollars toward specific foods, and the agricultural system that supplies them. It determines what food gets bought for school meals, child-care centers, senior-meal programs, and WIC food packages. It guides what foods the government buys for the military and federal cafeterias. It determines how SNAP educates low-income families about "healthy choices." In other words, when federal nutrition guidelines shift, the food system shifts with them. And with this new food pyramid, the food system will shift toward producing a lot more beef and dairy-the most resource-intensive and climate-polluting foods we produce at scale. Source: Project Drawdown Americans already eat far more beef and dairy than most of the wo

text: NVN Wednesday: LOOK UP AND LOOK OUT! by Ron Shapiro by Ron Shapiro NASA estimates there are more than 100 million pieces of space junk larger than 1 millimeter in diameter in LEO. Approximately 500,000 of those objects are between 1 and 10 centimeters, and more than 25,000 of them are greater than 10 centimeters wide. - Freethink , November 29, 2025 * Text within this block will maintain its original spacing when published On the darkest night of the year when stars glow like brilliant diamonds reminding us that we are indeed star dust that has taken human form on this planet, we should be grateful for the moonlight under which tides flow, nocturnal animals emerge from safe shelters and lovers kiss. Look up once more then slowly realize that what you thought were stars are actually more than 100 million pieces of rockets and satellites, tools discarded on spacewalks, junk floating in space. Here, on this planet, huge landfills stacked high like mountains with computers, electronics, batteries, styrofoam, ink cartridges, glass bottles, diapers, enough paper to fill several decimated forests and, of course, the toxic poisons released from human garbage. The Earth is not large enough to handle this waste. In a world that can seem like a warehouse of commodities, where capitalism begs for your dollars, once again human exceptionalism does not seem to care. Trash the planet or trash space, it's all the same to those in power. And once all that space junk begins to collide, sending more satellites into orbit will become too risky. Without such devices to enhance communication, predict weather patterns, bring about scientific breakthroughs. Even the possibility of intergalactic travel, the dreams of science fiction writers and futurists, writers and artists, will fall into darkness while humans, who once looked up to the stars for hope and creative inspiration, protect themselves from any space junk falling from the sky. * Ron Shapiro , an award-winning teacher, has published over 20 poems in publications including Nova Bar

text: Functional Medicine Can Treat Almost Anything Is it real or is it nonsense? I've been hearing a lot about Functional Medicine lately, particularly since the Trump administration nominated a functional medicine advocate , Casey Means, to be the Surgeon General. (Many months later, she hasn't been confirmed, so the position remains empty.) More recently, I heard effusive praise about functional medicine in a talk by someone from a longevity startup company, who shall remain nameless. I decided to take a deeper dive to find out what all the fuss was about. Thanks for reading Science and skepticism! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work. Well, let me tell you now: Functional Medicine is amazing!* Unlike conventional medicine (who likes that anyway?), it addresses the root causes of disease and treats the whole patient (not just the part that hurts!). It considers " a patient's genetic, environmental, and lifestyle influences " in order to design treatments that really, really work. Functional medicine doctors evaluate "a matrix of fundamental causes," which allows them to understand your illness far, far better than a regular doctor. How does this work? Well, as explained by Dr. Jeffrey Bland , the guy who invented functional medicine back in 1991, functional medicine pulls in ideas and techniques from holistic medicine, alternative medicine, traditional Chinese medicine, complementary medicine, and Ayurvedic medicine, and brings them all together in a unified framework. Wow, this just keeps getting better, doesn't it? I mean, all of those ideas pulled together in one place, that's brilliant! In this video of Jeffrey Bland discussing FM, he brings in the human genome project and how it revealed the "book of life" in 23 chapters (the chromosomes), and he refers to a "genotype-phenotype major paradigm shift." I was particularly intrigued here because I was part of the human genome project (I'm one of many co-authors on the original paper), and genomics is my field. text: The Cities That Saw Historic Murder Lows in 2025 Last year was a historic year in terms of the nation‚Äôs murder rate signalling the third straight year of record declines. Last year was a historic year in terms of the nation's murder rate signalling the third straight year of record declines. Murder likely fell at the fastest rate ever recorded and it was at or near a historic low in terms of the nation's murder rate. Thanks for reading Jeff-alytics! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work. It should come as no surprise that there are a number of large cities throughout the country that recorded historic lows in terms of the number and rate of murders in their borders. I count at least 12 such cities and three Honorable Mention cities that I think are worth pointing out. First, the Honoroable Mentions: New York City likely had the fewest shooting victims ever recorded in a year. The city's shooting victim data is only updated through September right now, but we can estimate the totals for the last three months using the aggregated counts on the police department's CompStat report . That report tends to slightly understate the number of shooting victims that show up each month in the open victim-level data. There were fewer shooting victims in New York City than any other year on record even though there were ever so slightly more murder victims this year (around 300) than the historic low of 2017 (292). It's worth noting that there were fewer people shot (fatally or nonfatally) in New York City this year (around 950) than were murdered there in any given year from 1968 to 1996. !function(){"use strict";window.addEventListener("message",(function(e){if(void 0!==e.data["datawrapper-height"]){var t=document.querySelectorAll("iframe");for(var a in e.data["datawrapper-height"])for(var r=0;r New Orleans, LA and Worcester, MA are the two other cities worth pointing out as Honorable Mentions. text: Jobs Report Recap (December) The First Good Jobs Report in a While TL;DR: After a string of bad BLS jobs reports, December's brought some good news, with a substantial decline in the unemployment rate. But the labor market is still in slightly worse shape than it was over the summer. Key Stats: Unemployment Rate: Fell to 4.38%, its lowest level since August (good) Nonfarm Payroll Employment: Rose by 50K in December, but big downward revisions to the prior two months (meh) Prime working age employment population ratio: inches up to 80.7% (good) The rest of this recap includes: The Big Picture Data Rundown Next Month: Benchmark Revision! More below chart. 1. The Big Picture December's jobs report was a good one - the 1st good one in a while. What do I mean by good? It certainly doesn't mean that everything is good in the labor market. Not everything in the report looked good. It doesn't negate the prior few jobs reports, which were bad. But it does, on the margin, change our perception of the state of the labor market: both where we are, and the pace at which we're moving. Where we are : the labor market has cooled a little bit in the past 6 months, but less than we previously thought. The pace at which we're moving: very gradually in the wrong direction, and a little more slowly than we previously thought. I've seen a lot of discourse on the report dwell on the meager employment growth - 50K in December, and only 584K in 2025 as a whole. For instance, you may have seen a chart like this, suggesting that 2025 was an unusually weak year for the labor market. I don't like that chart, because it is confounded by population growth. 2025 was a year with a big crackdown on immigration: both limiting who can come in, and trying to get people to leave. Simultaneously our population is aging. It's not surprising that in such an environment, you'd see much lower employment growth! You can't use this indicator to assess labor market health, at least from the perspective of slack. 1 2 A better perspective is looking at what happened to the unemp

text: Ten things that are going right in America Is our society slowly putting itself back together? Photo by Look Studio on Unsplash A lot of readers tell me that my fundamental optimism about the world is one of the reasons they appreciate my blog. I think my usual sunny attitude springs from my above-average skill at resisting the negativity bias inherent in the media. It's very easy to read the news every day and conclude that the world is in a never-ending hydra-headed " polycrisis "; if you have a cool, detached perspective, you'll realize that things are rarely so dark. That said, this year I was a bit of a downer. The coming of the second Trump administration means the end of the era of stability that the world enjoyed after World War 2. Even if the U.S. can fix its domestic problems (which are not all Trump's fault by a long stretch), the ascendance of China and Russia as the world's dominant power bloc will not be so easily undone, and the ramifications of that shift are only getting started. That's what motivated the somewhat darker tone of my blog this year. But that doesn't mean I think the world is going to Hell in a handbasket. From India's resilient economic growth to Europe's timely rearmament to the ongoing technological revolutions in AI , electric technology , and biotech, there is plenty to be happy about. Even when it comes to American society, I see lots of quiet reasons for optimism. Our politics is dysfunctional and our media landscape resembles a demon-haunted wasteland, but underneath the surface, I see signs that our society is starting to knit itself back together after the unrest and chaos of 2014-2021. Health is improving. Violence is falling. Americans are starting to use technology more responsibly. Some of the economic sclerosis of the pre-pandemic years seems to be falling away. I suspect that there are " macrosociological " forces at work. To my knowledge, sociologists haven't really modeled a cycle of aggregate social division and health, 1 but if you look at events like the collapse of the USSR and the decade of violence and se

text: Vanalla. A while back, I was talking to a friend about someone I had, at that point in time, very recently become acquainted with. A while back, I was talking to a friend about someone I had, at that point in time, very recently become acquainted with. We were discussing this person's sexual predilections - as you do, of course, when talking to your friends - and I mentioned in the course of conversation that the person in question was very kinky. Curious to know more, my friend asked about the specific areas of kinky interest held by this individual. "Well, anal," I initially responded. "Anal isn't kinky!" my friend replied. I have been thinking about that exchange ever since. I want to clarify here that when I described this person as both "very kinky" and "into anal," my point wasn't that they were some hardcore fetishist simply because happened to enjoy a rousing round of some good old fashioned up the butt. In this particular instance, I was talking about someone who was fascinated with the more extreme end of anal penetration: systematic trainings and anal expansion and penetrative elements of an eye popping girth. But I still think this question of, "Is anal sex inherently kinky?" is a good one to ponder. Is it possible to be into anal and still totally vanilla? What does that even mean? In the strictest sense of vanilla sex - the normative, and heteronormative, variety where you're doing missionary in the dark with the person you're legally wed to - I think anal absolutely counts as kinky, or at least non-vanilla, sex*. But if you expand your lens even slightly - and certainly if you expand it to include non-heterosexual sex - then the boundaries become even fuzzier. I, for one, can certainly imagine Pete and Chasten Buttigieg playing with each other's buttholes**. I cannot see the couple that cancelled a fundraiser at a gay bar over the presence of a stripper pole as engaging in anything remotely adjacent to kinky sex. text: Understanding The e/acc Movement The e/acc movement has billionaire backing and cosmic ambitions. History tells us that won‚Äôt be enough. Photo by Mathieu Stern on Unsplash The energy was palpable that day as hundreds of people pushed into the hotel ballroom. Many wearing grey coveralls, smiling, hopeful and showing the conviction of their vision. The Chief Engineer was speaking that morning. The world was about to become a better place. It was 1933 in California. Nearly a century later, this time with hoodies and t-shirts with slogans, people similarly poured into a hotel ballroom. the Head of Engineering for one of the larger AI companies was about to speak. The world was about to become a better place. That first effervescent event in 1933 was for the Technocracy movement. The one in the early 2020's was the e/acc (Effective Accelerationist) movement. Both times, these movements held their deepest convictions that anyone who questions the plan simply doesn't understand technology, physics. So the names may change, but the pattern hasn't. This is an essay looking at the evolution of the Technocracy ideals to today's e/acc movement. It is not so much to criticise them as to help people understand this movement and also why, ultimately, e/acc will fail just Technocracy did. Not because of their ideology (that doesn't help) but because of the broader invisible hand of culture and the realities of being human. The Technocracy Movement This movement started around 1919, after WWI by Howard Scott , an American born in 1890. By 1931, with some others, he'd formed Technocracy Inc., which was created to promote his ideas of a society run by engineers as he considered a society run by government and industry as wasteful. Boiled down, Technocrats thought the idea of money was a bit silly, and that energy was a much better form of fiat. More measurable and understandable, more concrete. Are you picking up some inklings of cryptocurrencies, blockchain and modern day technofeudalism here? There's a reason for that. The ideas of technocracy received a fair bit of attention in the USA and Canada in the early 1930s

text: The great silent majority of American basicness Read to the end for a good Douyin video The Stanley Cup Madness I first noticed the prevalence of the Stanley Quencher H2.0 FlowState™ tumbler last April when I wrote about #WaterTok. I'm still unclear what to make of #WaterTok, but I eventually settled on the idea that it's several subcultures overlapping - weight-loss communities, Mormons, and those people who don't like the "taste" of water. But in the majority of the #WaterTok videos I watched, people were using Stanley's Quencher to carry around their liquid Jolly Ranchers. And the ubiquity of the cup has sort of haunted me ever since. I grew up in the suburbs, but I don't live there anymore. So every time the great silent majority of American basicness summons a new totem to gather around, I can't help but try and make sense of it. Was this a car thing? A college football tailgate thing? An EDM thing? Cruise ships? Barstool Sports was of no help here, so I filed it away until this Christmas when it exploded across the web and forced me to finally figure out what the heck was going on. And it turns out, the Stanley cup's transformation into a must-have last year is actually, in many ways, the story of everything now. CNBC put together a great explainer on this. Stanley, a manly hundred-year-old brand primarily aimed at hikers and blue-collar workers, was rediscovered in 2019 by the bloggers behind a women's lifestyle and shopping site called The Buy Guide. They told CNBC that even though the Quencher model of the cup was hard to find, no other cup on the market had what they were looking for. Which is a bizarrely passionate stance to take on a water bottle, but from their post about the cup, those attributes were: "Large enough to keep up with our busy days, a handle to carry it wherever we go, dishwasher safe, fits into our car cupholders, keeps ice cold for 12+ hours, and a straw." The Buy Guide team then sent a Quencher to Emily Maynard Johnson from The Bachelor after she had a baby because "there is no thirst like nursing mom thirst!" Johns

text: Breaking precedent, networks interrupt prime time for Trump political diatribe On Wednesday night at 9 PM Eastern, President Trump delivered a prime time address to the nation that was aired by all major broadcast networks. President Trump addresses the nation from the White House on December 17, 2025. (Photo by Doug MILLS / POOL / AFP via Getty Images) On Wednesday night at 9 PM Eastern, President Trump delivered a prime time address to the nation that was aired by all major broadcast networks. It preempted the season finale of "Survivor" on CBS , one of the network's most highly-rated shows, the season finale of "The Floor" on Fox, and holiday specials on ABC and NBC. Typically, networks will interrupt their primetime schedule for presidents to address wars, crises, or very significant new policies. In his remarks on Wednesday, Trump delivered his standard talking points, bragging about his mass deportation policies and tariffs and attacking Democrats and the Biden administration. The only crisis was Trump's sagging approval ratings . "Over the past 11 months, we have brought more positive change to Washington than any administration in American history," Trump said during the speech. "There's never been anything like it." Trump blamed the Democrats for the increased cost of health insurance. "You see that now in the steep increase in premiums being demanded by the Democrats, and they are demanding those increases, and it's their fault," he said. Millions of Americans will see their insurance rates increase after Republicans refused to extend government subsidies that will expire at the end of the year . The speech's partisan political content was not a surprise. White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt said that Trump would address the country "about all of his historic accomplishments over the past year" and " all that he's done to bring our country back to greatness ." Specifically, Leavitt stated that Trump would likely discuss " border security and lower gas prices ." The networks decided to break precedent and air it anyway. The networks have declined to air prime time speeches from the last two Democratic presidents, claiming they were too political. In 2022, for example,

text: Will the LMS Finally Deliver? Matthew Pittinsky has been on the front lines of the LMS world for three decades, beginning in 1995. Matthew Pittinsky has been on the front lines of the LMS world for three decades, beginning in 1995. An early participant in the Instructional Management Systems Project (IMS), a co-founder of Blackboard , a board member at Instructure , and now a senior executive at Anthology/Blackboard, Pittinsky occupies a unique vantage point-as a "30-year observer and participant" in LMS leadership. His two-part retrospective and prospective on the LMS is therefore must-reading. It offers rare insight into what has shaped "LMS thinking" over the past three decades-and what that thinking might look like in a world shaped by AI. The LMS at 30 In Part I, The LMS at 30: From Course Management to Learning Management (At Last) , Pittinsky begins by noting that 2025 "marks a milestone in the Internet's impact on education: the 30th anniversary of the Learning Management System (LMS)." He goes on to observe that none of the major technology platform shifts during this period-such as SaaS and mobile-fundamentally changed the LMS. Pittinsky reviews several other factors over this thirty-year span, but ultimately concludes: "Today's LMS may be more scalable, prettier and easier to provision, but presented side-by-side, an LMS course Web site today closely resembles those from 1999. Indeed, it is remarkable how much even the strategic framing of today's LMS is the same as then." In other words, today's LMS is essentially the same system we had three decades ago. This is a stunning admission. A Stunning Admission-from the Inside It is stunning not because it comes from a critic of the LMS, but because it comes from someone who helped build it, scale it, and defend it for thirty years. Pittinsky is not arguing that the LMS fell short of its ambitions. He is acknowledging something more consequential: that, instructionally, the LMS never truly changed. In fact, the problem is worse than stasis. The core learning model did not stagnate-it never got off the ground. Across three decades, the LMS

text: What a simple question about My Cousin Vinny taught me about LLMs If you want to see an LLM really malfunction, ask it to reconstruct a story from pieces. Also: Should this be a benchmark? We live in weird times. I tried to start this post repeatedly, with half a dozen different openings. And that's what I end up with: we live in weird times. Existing benchmarks for LLM performance are getting saturated. People run around saying meaningless things like "This AI has moved from college senior level intelligence to PhD level intelligence." Other people hear these things and nod their heads. I look around and see the nodding and hear these meaningless phrases and think I'm losing my mind. Maybe you do too? I don't see myself as "pro-AI" or "anti-AI." But I understand how the AI doubters feel. They read about the myriad successes of LLMs, and then they ask an LLM a question about something they actually know and get a bizarre answer. Pressed later for an example of an error, they can't remember, but they are pretty sure they see errors in output all the time. People tell them they are wrong and imagining things, that these issues were solved long ago. They feel a bit gaslit. I'm here to tell you the errors they see are real. I also know how the people boosting AI feel. If you've been paying attention to response quality over the last year it's been an amazing year of progress. Answers have gotten remarkably better. Yet AI doubters are talking about stalling progress. How is that possible? I think both of these issues stem - at least partially - from having a set of metrics that don't capture well the daily experience of these systems. Both in how they still malfunction horribly at weirdly basic things and in how they have dramatically improved over time. And I want to tell that story in a way that I hope will lead to greater détente by discussing the 1992 comedy My Cousin Vinny . A Simple Question Let's ask an LLM what seems like a simple question. I swear I have not chosen this question as a trick. I haven't tried to find a way to fool AI for hours. This isn't "glue on pizza" nonsense or "How many rocks should I eat a day?" both of which are question

text: On Hatereading as Method Ridicule is our last, best weapon I wasn't going to read Olivia Nuzzi 's new book, American Canto . It isn't, strictly speaking, in my wheelhouse. But I had some time available between the end of classes and final exam submission. And I do love a good hateread. My standard approach is to create a reaction thread on Bluesky, and treat that as the first draft of a proper book review. Then I trim it down and turn it into a book review that resides on Substack. I don't see any point in turning the Nuzzi review into a substack post though. There have already been plenty of sharp - witted review , appropriately cataloguing the book's failings. I don't have much to add beyond the hyperlinks. ( My review thread starts here , for my non-bluesky-addicted readers). Instead, I'd like to take a step back and discuss hatereading as a genre. Because I'm clearly enjoying myself with this, but I've never paused to think through what it is exactly that I'm doing here. This is the eighth hateread-thread that I've composed this year. It has become something of a running bit. (A couple people referred to me this week as "Bluesky's Omelas child" and ohmygodIlovethat.) The other books I reviewed were (1) Future Shock , (2) The Network State (far and away the worst book I've ever read) (3), Abundance ( Which I didn't actually hate, mind you), (4) After the Spike: Population, Progress, and the Case for People , (5) Boom: Bubbles and Stagnation , (6) If Anyone Builds It, Everyone Dies . I also wrote a thread about Alex Karp's The Technological Republic , but I didn't post a link to Substack and can't track it down now. What I look for in a hateread candidate is something that deserves it. The book has to have some juice. Most of these books come from Silicon Valley intellectuals, or from leading thinkers that Silicon Valley takes seriously. text: How to Network When You're an Introvert Stephanie Thoma, Confident Introvert Courtesy of Stephanie Thoma For a profession that requires regularly talking to strangers, journalism has a fair share of introverts. That's usually not a problem when they're reporting, a highly structured activity that gives you the excuse of asking prying questions on behalf of your readers or even the general public. But it can be a problem when it comes time to network. Meeting up with other journalists at a social function? Self-promotion? Small talk? For the average introvert, those all sound exhausting. So how do you do it? By turning your natural instincts from a disadvantage into an advantage and using your skills as a reporter. We talked with Stephanie Thoma, a career coach who specializes in helping introverts , about some tips for networking for introverted journalists. Do some reporting: Look for some journalists likely to attend the event and read up on their background and their recent stories. Treat it like a potential interview. This will also give you something to talk about, which should reduce anxiety. Use social media: Find the contacts you're hoping to make on public-facing social media sites such as BlueSky or Threads and interact with them. This establishes some rapport for when you might meet in person in a low-stress way. Go early: There will be fewer people there, which can reduce your stress. It's also easier to chat with the handful of other early birds than trying to work a crowded room like an extrovert. Find the introverts: Look for the people hanging out on the edges of the room and strike up a conversation. They're probably introverts too and will be glad that you took the first step. Thoma recommends having a couple of staple openers: "I call these conversational sponges: open ended, and inspiring further conversation. One of my favorites is ‘What's something you're looking forward to right now?'" Have an elevator pitch: Try to come up with a brief description of who you are and what you do. If you have a job, give our name,

text: This week on How I AI: Zapier's CEO shares his personal AI stack Your weekly listens from How I AI, part of the Lenny's Podcast Network Every Monday, host Claire Vo shares a 30- to 45-minute episode with a new guest demoing a specific, practical, and impactful way they've learned to use AI in their work or life. No pontificating-just practical and actionable advice. Zapier's CEO shares his personal AI stack Brought to you by Brex -The intelligent finance platform built for founders In this episode, Wade Foster (co-founder & CEO of Zapier) shares the actual way he's leading real AI adoption inside Zapier-by using it hands-on himself to understand company culture, evaluate candidates, and find talent most recruiters never see. We get concrete workflows Wade uses everyday: building interview-evaluation agents, using tools like Grok to surface diamonds-in-the-rough candidates, and analyzing meeting transcripts to uncover Zapier's "unspoken culture." He also explains why AI fluency can't be delegated, how leaders should create safe "play spaces" for experimentation, and why the definition of "top talent" is rapidly changing. Biggest takeaways: CEOs must do more than write an "AI memo." Wade sees many executives fall into the "delegation trap"-writing a memo about AI adoption then expecting it to filter down through the organization. Instead, leaders should create "play spaces" like hackathons and show-and-tells where teams can experiment with AI tools without pressure. You can build an interview evaluation agent in minutes. Wade demonstrated a simple Zapier agent that analyzes interview transcripts against job descriptions and company values, then recommends whether to advance candidates. This provides an unbiased second opinion that helps catch things human interviewers might miss. Use Grok to find "diamonds in the rough" talent. While most recruiters focus on LinkedIn, Wade uses Grok to search X/Twitter and YouTube for potential candidates who match specific criteria. This surfaces people who might never appear in traditional recruiting channels-especially in communities that are active on these platfo

text: The Trifecta Nature of Man: Jung, Theology, and the Architecture of the Mind How body, soul, and spirit shape consciousness, meaning and human wholeness. To become a person of intellectual competence, it is important to understand the history of one's own mind. This is arguably the root of all language, human thought, inventions, creativity, and ideas. Its understanding can be paramount to the mastery of everything else: from science and mathematics, to chess, critical thinking, or playing an instrument. Ultimate understanding requires teachings from the quintessence of man, and (for many) the omniscience of his Creator. Naturally, one turns to Carl Jung to evaluate his work on the psyche, which encompasses all conscious and unconscious processes. Theology, too, has a role to play in this, and is perhaps the elemental forum (alpha and omega) for understanding the mysteries of our mind. Other multidisciplinary factors (history, science and archaeology) also influence how our mental capacities came to be. But for the purposes of this article, psychology and theology will be the focal point. The Thinking Archive is a reader-supported publication. To receive new posts and support my work, consider becoming a free or paid subscriber. The Trifecta Nature of Man The triune, as it is also called, is the view that man is composed of three distinct parts: the body, soul, and spirit. This primarily comes from Christian theology, and readers familiar with the Bible may recognise it from 1 Thessalonians 5:23. 1 Plato explored an idea of a triune in his work, ‘ The Republic ' (c.375 BCE) and in ‘ Phaedrus ', (c.370 BCE) where he conceptualised the soul by dividing it into three parts. 2 But simply speaking, the theological concept of the triune can be understood in this way: The body is our biology. It consists of the flesh, the senses, and the nervous system, and is the element that roots us in the material world. It is therefore perceptible to the physical, and deals with tactile, palpable matters. The soul is our mind. It is the part of man where reason is expressed using rationality and thought. This is also man's

text: Chaos Why Knowing the Rules Does Not Mean Owning the Future... Most people are not especially interested in chaos theory, and they are right not to be. What they care about instead is a simpler, more practical question: why does so much confident planning fail so badly, even when it is done by clever people with good data and sophisticated tools? Why do policies that are carefully modelled, systems that are meticulously managed, and futures that are aggressively forecast so often dissolve into surprise, escalation, and excuse? We are told, repeatedly, that understanding is improving, that prediction is becoming more accurate, and that authority therefore deserves greater trust. This essay asks whether that inference is actually warranted. Chaos theory enters the discussion not as a technical curiosity, but as a hard-won lesson about the limits of foresight - and about what those limits do, and do not, entitle us to claim. We grow up absorbing a conviction so basic it is almost invisible: that to understand a rule is to gain advance sight. The kettle boils; the door opens; the clock advances. Learn how something works, and you can say what will happen next. The world appears to reward comprehension with foresight, as though intelligence were a kind of temporal privilege. This is not a philosophical doctrine so much as a habit of expectation, trained into us by a lifetime of small, obedient systems that behave as they are told. That habit rests on an assumption rarely stated aloud: that causes behave proportionally. Push a little, and a little happens. Push twice as hard, and twice as much follows. When things go wrong, they usually go wrong in recognisable ways. Errors remain modest, contained, civilised. Even failure is legible. In such a world, understanding feels like control delayed. Learn the rule, and the future yields - if not immediately, then eventually. For a long time, science assumed that this picture generalised. When prediction failed, the explanation seemed obvious: the equations were too complex, the measurements

It's a predictable outcome when powerful tools are released without meaningful protections-and when app stores and operating systems fail to enforce their own rules. text: Self-driving cars aren‚Äôt nearly a solved problem Contrary to popular belief, Waymos aren't actually fully autonomous, and the problem is harder than it may seem Photo by gibblesmash asdf Self-driving cars are not a solved problem, nor are they close to getting solved. I will explain further, but since this is a case where the messenger matters more than the message, first listen to Andrej Karpathy tell you the same thing. Karpathy is as credentialed as it comes: he was the lead AI researcher responsible for the development of Tesla's Full Self-Driving software from 2017 to 2022. (Karpathy also did two stints as a researcher at OpenAI, taught a deep learning course at Stanford, and coined the term "vibe coding".) Here's a long quote from Karpathy's October 17, 2025 interview with Dwarkesh Patel: Dwarkesh Patel 01:42:55 You've talked about how you were at Tesla leading self-driving from 2017 to 2022. And you firsthand saw this progress from cool demos to now thousands of cars out there actually autonomously doing drives. Why did that take a decade? What was happening through that time? Andrej Karpathy 01:43:11 One thing I will almost instantly push back on is that this is not even near done, in a bunch of ways that I'm going to get to. Self-driving is very interesting because it's definitely where I get a lot of my intuitions because I spent five years on it. It has this entire history where the first demos of self-driving go all the way to the 1980s. You can see a demo from CMU in 1986 . There's a truck that's driving itself on roads. Fast forward. When I was joining Tesla, I had a very early demo of Waymo. It basically gave me a perfect drive in 2014 or something like that, so a perfect Waymo drive a decade ago. It took us around Palo Alto and so on because I had a friend who worked there. I thought it was very close and then it still took a long time. For some kinds of tasks and jobs and so on, there's a very large demo-to-product gap where the demo is very easy, but the product is very hard. It's especially the case in cases like self-driving where the cost of failure is too high. Many industries, tasks, and jobs maybe do

Diana's Substack is a reader-supported publication. To receive new posts and support my work, consider becoming a free or paid subscriber. Because I don't know if Mo ever actually existed. For all I know, he may have been AI all along. His name has even been removed as co-author of the previous Palestine Clarity Manual posts. He no longer has a Substack account. We were using a google doc to write this manual, and yesterday I no longer had access to it. So I emailed him at what I assumed was his real name - Zaffar Hussain (zaffarh@gmail.com), the name he shared on Substack as his LinkedIn profile. Fair enough. I understand the privacy concerns. When I checked Substack today, there was no trace of this person, who had listed himself as a retired government employee from California. There was, however, a listing for someone on LinkedIn by this name who was the CEO of HYZ Energy of Qatar. At one point during the recent holiday season, he emailed me to say he'd be returning to Ireland from Scotland in a few days so wouldn't be working on the manual at that time. I didn't think much of it. People move, and don't update their LinkedIn profiles sometimes. I didn't give him any personal information, and we interacted via email and google docs only, so no Zoom calls. Still, it's bewildering and feels like a betrayal. He was pleasant and easy - maybe too easy - to interact with, and I loved his writing style. Anyways, at this point I'm trying to figure out what to make of this. I was going to leave this post for a week or so, but thought it important to get this out. As a warning, as a way of processing, and as something that I thought would be of interest. Anyways, all, take care. We live and learn, and learn from the experiences of others. text: What did the Romans Think of Lesbian Sex? Acta Populi - Number XIV Sappho and Alcaeus, 1881, by Lawrence Alma-Tadema (1836–1912) Now here's a subject that's going to get your attention! There's going to be some exciting language in this, which I have kept a bit adult, because that is very much the context in which it was meant. So be warned! In Roman society, sexual activity was understood primarily in terms of dominance, power, and social order rather than boring old personal pleasure on its own. Roman discourse on sex frequently emphasised penetrative acts, hierarchical roles, and the public perception of sexual morality. Female-to-female sexual acts, therefore, were judged through this slightly skewed view of activity and power. For Roman authors, sex was often defined in quite functional and hierarchical terms. Penetration was the central concept, frequently associated with the active, dominant role of the penetrator. Sexual acts without penetration were sometimes dismissed as incomplete or ineffective in establishing social meaning (Veyne, 1990). As these acts were seen to be incomplete, it was considered that sex had not really occurred. This central concept still remains in some Western laws, such as in the UK, where ‘rape' is defined as penetration with a penis. Anything else is ‘sexual assault'. The framework of dominance and submission was integral to Roman sexual ideology: the penetrator held power, while the receptive partner assumed a subordinate position. In this context, sexual acts between women presented an ambiguity, as neither partner fit the traditional hierarchy. Both could be dominant, both could be subservient, both could be neither, and to Romans, this made no sense as a sexual act. It was, in effect, ‘messing around'. Martial's Epigrams provide some of the most direct literary references to female-female sexual acts. In Epigrams 7.67, Martial writes of Philaenis, a lesbian, who has fun getting up to all sorts of mischief with boys and girls. She sodomises boys, refuses to give men bl

text: Insanity redux: Shock and awe in Venezuela Almost the only difference between what you saw on television today and what you saw in 2003 is that Donald Trump didn't put on a flight suit and land on an aircraft carrier to announce his Venezuelan "mission accomplished." Baghdad? No, bombs over Caracas last night Almost the only difference between what you saw on television today and what you saw in 2003 is that Donald Trump didn't put on a flight suit and land on an aircraft carrier to announce his Venezuelan "mission accomplished." Along with a bunch of guys in suits standing stone-faced in front of American flags, every element of the madness that got us involved in the mess that was our misbegotten attempt to take over Iraq was there: It's going to pay for itself. Remember that one? The invasion of Iraq won't cost us a penny because…oil. Trump said the same thing about six times today. "We'll probably make a little profit," he bragged. "We're going to have our very large United States oil companies, the biggest anywhere in the world, go in, spend billions of dollars, fix the badly broken infrastructure, the oil infrastructure, and start making money for the country, and we are ready to stage a second and much larger attack if we need to do so." Okaaaaay… We're designating various people to run Venezuela. Who is going to be in charge there, now that they don't have a president? "We're going to let you know who those people are that would run Venezuela. It's largely going to be for a period of time, the people that are standing right behind me. We're going to be running it." Somebody should find Paul Bremer, the incompetent dingbat who ran the Coalition Provisional Authority, and ask him how that worked out in Iraq. He was the U.S. Presidential Envoy and Administrator of Iraq after Bush fired the retired general he had first put in the job. Bremer was the genius who disbanded the Iraqi army and outlawed the Baath Party, Saddam Hussein's regime that ran the country, plunging Iraq into sectarian warfare and the insurgency that turned into what we now call the war in Iraq. But there won't be any problems in Venezuela, will there? I mean, all we're doing is taking their oil. Oh, I almost forgot. It's a snap of the fingers!

text: JWST Discovers a Lava World That's Clinging to Its Atmosphere ‚Äì TOI-561 b Defies the Odds TOI-561 b: The Hottest Rocky World That Should Be Airless‚Ä¶ But Isn‚Äôt Artist's concept showing TOI-561 b orbiting its ancient star, with a thick atmosphere hovering over endless magma oceans. Credit: NASA, ESA, CSA, Ralf Crawford (STScI) What if we told you there's a planet out there so blisteringly hot that its entire surface is a churning sea of molten rock – yet it somehow manages to hold onto a thick, steamy atmosphere? That's the jaw-dropping revelation from NASA's James Webb Space Telescope, which has just given us the clearest evidence yet of air on a rocky exoplanet this extreme. Meet TOI-561 b, a super-Earth that's rewriting the playbook on planetary survival. This isn't some sci-fi fever dream; it's real data from Webb's NIRSpec instrument, peering at a world orbiting its star in under 11 hours. The dayside? A global magma ocean glowing at temperatures that would vaporize steel. But instead of being a barren, airless husk like we expected, TOI-561 b is wrapped in a volatile-rich blanket – think water vapor, carbon dioxide, and maybe even silicate clouds acting like a cosmic shield. The team behind this, led by Johanna Teske from Carnegie Science, was stunned. "What really sets this planet apart is its anomalously low density," Teske explained in the new paper out today. At 1.4 times Earth's size but with a puffier build, it hinted at something more than just rock and iron. Webb's 37-hour stare-down confirmed it: the planet's dayside is "only" 1,800°C, way cooler than the 2,700°C predicted for bare lava. That cooling? Winds whipping heat around, gases absorbing infrared light, and clouds reflecting starlight back to space. Why does this matter? For starters, it flips the script on ultra-short-period exoplanets – those hellish worlds we thought were doomed to lose their air billions of years ago. TOI-561 b orbits a star twice the Sun's age in a metal-poor corner of the galaxy, so it might be a fossil from the Universe's early days. "It's really like a wet lava ball," says co-author Tim Lichtenberg f

text: History of the Present: From Simplicity to Complexity‚Äîand Back Again How the same forces that allow complexity, intelligence, and abundance to arise may also make advanced civilizations fragile‚Äîand why survival depends on coordination as much as discovery. At the Edge of Becoming: From Simplicity to Complexity, And Back. Webb's First Deep Field shows the galaxy cluster SMACS 0723 as it looked 4.6 billion years ago, with its enormous gravity bending and magnifying light from far more distant galaxies behind it, allowing thousands of otherwise invisible galaxies to be seen in exceptional detail using public-domain imagery produced by NASA (the United States' space agency), ESA (the European Space Agency), and CSA (the Canadian Space Agency). We do not know whether the Big Bang was a true beginning. It may have been the origin of everything, or it may have emerged from the end state of something else-a collapse, a transition, a phase change beyond our present capacity to describe. We do not know what preceded it, if anything did, nor whether the frameworks we use to model it will survive future discoveries. Our knowledge of the universe is partial, provisional, and subject to revision. More unsettling still, we do not know the shape or scale of what we do not know. Modern cosmology-from dark matter and dark energy to quantum behavior that resists classical intuition-reminds us how incomplete our understanding remains. And yet, imperfect as it is, some understanding exists. Something happened. "Systems that reduce constraint also concentrate risk, and when complexity grows faster than coordination, collapse becomes a feature rather than a failure." Roughly 13.8 billion years ago-according to our best current measurements and models-the observable universe emerged from an early phase we can only partially reconstruct. In that phase, matter and energy behaved in ways that appear, from our limited vantage point, relatively simple compared with the complexity that followed. Whether this apparent simplicity was fundamental, emergent, or merely an artifact of incomplete theory remains unknown. What followed, as far as we can observe, was the emergence of structure. Particles formed. Atoms assembled. Matter gathered into stars a

text: The Bridge to Nowhere: Why $12 Billion in USDA Aid Still Leaves Soybean Farmers Underwater On December 8, 2025, the USDA announced the Farmer Bridge Assistance (FBA) Program. On December 8, 2025, the USDA announced the Farmer Bridge Assistance (FBA) Program. The program will provide $12 billion in one-time assistance payments to producers of specific crops, including barley, chickpeas, corn, cotton, lentils, oats, peanuts, peas, rice, sorghum, soybeans, wheat, canola, crambe, flax, mustard, rapeseed, safflower, sesame, and sunflower. Farmers were required to file their acreage reports by December 19, 2025 to be eligible, and the USDA expects to release payments by the end of February 2026. On December 31, 2025 , USDA announced payment rates for specific commodities. An article from Farmdoc Daily of the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign has outlined that the program payments will be calculated by simply multiplying the number of acres planted to a specific commodity to the corresponding payment rate. An operation that grew 500 acres of cotton will see a payment of $58,675 ($117.35 x 500) and an operation that grew 312 acres of soybeans would receive a payment of $9,635 ($30.88 x 312). Farmdoc provided an example of a farm in Illinois in their analysis: "A farm with 50% of its acres planted to corn and the other half planted to soybeans would receive an average FBA payment of $37.62 per acre (0.5 x $44.36 + 0.5 x $30.88). The average size of a grain farm enrolled in Illinois Farm Business Farm Management (FBFM) is roughly 1,500 acres. Total FBA payments for the average grain farm with only owned and cash rented acres in Illinois with 750 acres planted to corn and 750 acres planted to soybeans in 2025 would be $56,430 ($44.36 x 750 corn acres plus $30.88 x 750 soybean acres)." USDA's fact sheet sets payment limitation for the program at $155,000 per producer and only operations making less than $900,000 in adjusted gross income will be eligible for the program. This is very consistent with other Farm Service Agency commodity programs. USDA has outlined that acres which were prevented from being planted are ineligible for FBA. By exclu

text: Pipeline wars Let's say you are an American president, and you decide that with all the oil being produced in your own country – the U.S. Decaying Venezuelan oil pipeline: Bloomberg Let's say you are an American president, and you decide that with all the oil being produced in your own country – the U.S. is the world's top oil producer, pumping more than 13 million barrels a day – that is not enough. You want more oil. You want oil from Iraq. You want oil from Syria. Those places are far, far away, in the Middle East. And then you look south, in your own hemisphere, and you see Venezuela, and you think, I'd like some oil from there. We used to have American oil companies in that South American country. Then in 1976 – 50 years ago – Venezuela nationalized its oil industry and took over the oil fields and infrastructure built by American oil companies. You are an American president whose favorite word, next to "billions," is "unfair." You think to yourself, how unfair it was to take all that oil away from U.S. oil companies. You don't like the president who's running Venezuela, this Maduro guy, because he doesn't show you the respect you think you are due as the King of All That You See. So, you decide you'll get rid of the disrespectful dictator of Venezuela, and you will take the oil. You see yourself as much, much smarter than the bumbling George W. Bush, whose major error, when he invaded Iraq to get rid of its disrespectful dictator, Saddam Hussein, did not take the oil. You ignore the fact that the Bush family – Junior and Senior both – were in the oil business in Texas, so they at least knew something of what was involved in taking the oil, whether it was out of the ground in the U.S. or out of a foreign country such as Iraq. You think you are smarter than George W. Bush because you know a lot of oil men. They supported your campaign in 2024. They have come to visit you at your resort/hotel/home in Palm Beach, Mar a Lago, and they have come to visit you in the White House. Some of those oil men run the companies whose oil was stolen from them back in 1976. They

text: The Digital Acceleration vs. The Institutional Inertia The trajectory of human progress over the last quarter-century has created a profound civilizational schism. The trajectory of human progress over the last quarter-century has created a profound civilizational schism. We have moved from the tactile simplicity of playing "Snake" on a Nokia handset to the sophisticated neural architectures of the "Nvidia AI Zone" in less than three decades. In the grand timeline of human history, thirty years is a mere blink; yet, this brief window has birthed a technological reality that our foundational institutions-many of them centuries or even millennia old-are fundamentally unequipped to navigate. ​The Velocity of Innovation ​The transition from basic mobile gaming to generative artificial intelligence represents an exponential leap in cognitive and social infrastructure. For Millennials and Gen Z, this shift is not merely a change in tools, but a transformation of culture, communication, and power dynamics. Digital native generations operate in a world of decentralization, instant feedback, and meritocratic data. ​The Weight of Archaic Institutions ​In stark contrast to this rapid evolution, our political and social structures remain anchored in the "Legacy of Kings." From the centralized authority of Caesar to the symbolic but systemic presence of King Charles, the mechanisms of power continue to reflect an era of hereditary rule and rigid hierarchy. These institutions were designed for a world of slow information and physical borders-a world that no longer exists in the digital age. ​The persistence of these "archaic institutions" creates a friction point with modern values. The throne, as a symbol of inherited power, struggles to find justification in a culture that increasingly prioritizes: ​Transparency over royal mystique. ​Agility over bureaucratic tradition. ​Equity over bloodline-based privilege. ​A Growing Disconnect ​The tension described is not merely aesthetic; it is functional. RTZ #961 ...new 'code red' reality across AI driven PCs, smartphones & devices for 2026 and beyond I went out of my way to highlight across several 2025 year-end pieces, that memory chip shortages, and resulting price increases, would be one of the biggest headwinds in 2026 for the AI Tech Wave . Especially for memory chip in local AI devices like PCs, laptops, smartphones and more. Yes, US/China trade and tariff issues , along with regulatory matters will be an additional headwind as well, but the memor chip issue, driven in particular by the extraordinary AI Data Center and Power build up this year and beyond, will be a secular reality for the next couple of years at least. That is a picture being borne out at CES 2026 . There's a ‘best of times, worst of times' dynamic going on. On the former front, we're seeing the expected flood of AI powered PCs, laptops, smartphones and a plethora of devices, with more AI capabilities than ever. On the ‘worst of times' front, the prices when they're available, are inducing ‘sticker shock' for tech industry folks used to seeing Moore's Law Driven lower prices with higher features for decades now. And the details are worth noting and absorbing . The Verge has a piece worth reading in full on the current snapshot from CES 2026. Some highlights from "The PC market braces for an AI-driven storm": "Building a PC or buying one is about to get even pricier". "The personal computer has remained surprisingly resilient to change over the past 15 years. Apple promised a "post-PC" era with the iPad in 2010 and failed to deliver one. Smartphones even overtook laptops as the most popular device to connect to the internet a decade ago, but millions of people still kept buying PCs every year. But this PC resiliency is going to be tested even further this year." Not to mention smartphones, which are also dependent on rising memory chip minimums to at least 16GB (gigabytes) from previous base levels of 8GB. text: Your Syllabus and Academic Freedom Making an affirmative case for the values that underpin our work. The University of North Carolina recently declared that all faculty syllabi are "public records," meaning they are open to all, a decision which mirrors previous actions in Florida and Texas. At its heart, a syllabus is a statement of purpose, rooted in the values that will inform the course and class experience. These statements have become contested around politics because they have become another locus for political and ideological actors to attempt to exert control through surveillance and intimidation. These intrusions are reaching truly absurd heights. A social media post from the AAUP chapter at Texas A&M shared a portion of an administrative email to a faculty member instructing that Plato must be removed from the course readings to conform with restrictions on content on "race ideology" and "gender ideology." To help push back against these forces, the Center for the Defense of Academic Freedom has developed language and academic freedom resources that can be introduced directly into syllabi as a way to assert these rights and also create a productive atmosphere for faculty and students alike. We released these materials last Fall, but thought they might deserve another period in the spotlight, so we're republishing our original piece by Isaac Kamola. - John Warner Putting Academic Freedom on the Syllabus Issac Kamola, Director, Center for the Defense of Academic Freedom (Originally published August 26, 2025) Compiling a syllabus is a particularly daunting these days-especially for those who are experiencing threats by politicians, administrators, or donors to determine what can be discussed within our classrooms. We all take so much care putting together our readings, assignments, and classroom policies, weighing pros and cons, considering how to address issues that arose last time we taught the class. These threats are a new issue-an issue that can't be ignored, but one that is also very difficult to address. In response to these threats, the AAUP's Cente

text: What we can (and can't) learn from California It's a useful but limited look at national politics. I'm Isaac Saul, and this is Tangle: an independent, ad-free, subscriber-supported politics newsletter that summarizes the best arguments from across the political spectrum on the news of the day - then "my take." Today's issue is a special Friday edition. First time reading? Sign up here . A month ago, California Gov. Gavin Newsom looked like he might be in trouble. Today, Newsom looks less like a political survivor and more like someone who easily flexed his political muscle to stay in office. When I first covered the recall election , FiveThirtyEight had California voters leaning to keep Newsom as governor by a mere percentage point. Folks on the left were already writing his obituary while criticizing the Democratic party for overlooking the recall and not taking the threat seriously enough. Meanwhile, the right had coalesced not just around removing Newsom, but around replacing him with Larry Elder, the most popular conservative on the ballot, a talk radio host whose following appeared to be boosting him in the polls. In the end, 6.1 million Californians voted to keep Newsom, and 3.4 million voted to remove him, a 63.7 percent to 36.3 percent margin. The question now is: What to make of it? No matter how much Democrats want this to be a sign of strength, I'm not sure it is. California Gov. Gavin Newsom. Photo: Gage Skidmore Yes, Newsom over-performed most of the polling. And yes, despite all the hype, he held off the recall effort rather easily. But Democrats outnumber Republicans by nearly 2 to 1 in California, and it took a visit from President Joe Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris; it took a media frenzy; it took a rotating cast of Democratic celebrities encouraging people to turn out and vote. It was clear, based both on how Newsom campaigned in the final weeks and how the Democratic party addressed this, that team blue broke a sweat. And in California, the momentum this recall had is not a great sign. This is a state Donald Trump lost by nearly 30 poin

text: When Change Outruns Us Why growth depends on absorption and recovery In 2007, Nokia was unstoppable. The Finnish company sold more phones than Apple, Samsung, and Motorola combined. Its market share hovered near 40 percent, its margins were envied across Europe, and its brand was a symbol of reliability. Inside the company's sprawling Espoo campus, engineers spoke in the language of precision and process. Decisions were documented, metrics tracked, and procedures refined. Nokia didn't improvise; it executed. But then came the iPhone. What followed wasn't a single transformation, it was a dozen. Between 2005 and 2010, Nokia reorganized its leadership structure six times. It spun up new software divisions, launched competing internal projects, and replaced process after process in a desperate attempt to rediscover its agility. On paper, the company was moving fast. In reality, it was exhausting itself. According to a case study by Harvard Business Review titled Nokia: The Inside Story of the Rise and Fall of a Technology Giant , the pace of internal change became so relentless that employees stopped resisting it altogether. "We were constantly reorganizing," one executive recalled, "but never really improving." Managers grew fearful of voicing skepticism because tomorrow's process might make today's priorities irrelevant. Even when engineers recognized the threat of Apple's software ecosystem, they had no energy left to fight through another round of reorgs. The company's culture didn't calcify, it frayed. That's how Nokia lost the race it had once dominated. It didn't die from complacency. It died from exhaustion. And that exhaustion has a name. Researchers call it the acceleration trap , a state where organizations push so hard to stay adaptive that they outpace their own ability to absorb change. A similar pattern appears in research published by the American Psychological Association , which reports that workers experiencing recent or current change were more than twice as likely to report chronic work stress compared with employee
label: technical

text: Enacting Courage Pulling Up the Tangled Roots of Injustice Its a new year and a time for setting intentions. On New Year's Day 2022, I set an intention to express more interpersonal warmth and I refreshed that intention each year thereafter - until this year. Since the 2024 election I've been feeling the need for enacting more courage . Just writing this down creates a stirring in the core of my body, so I know its an edge. Putting things to paper helps increase my commitment. Enacting courage is my intention for 2026. As I understand it, courage means facing fear, difficulty, uncertainty - a willingness to risk. And the kind of courage I would like to cultivate involves more than a single act of heroism in a rare emergency - like running into a house on fire to save a child. I wish to build the fortitude to stay - to hold the line of my aspirational values. I've learned over the years that true confidence (unlike bravado or hubris) arises out of enacted courage, and I certainly could use a bigger dose of that. Revolution From the Inside Out is a reader-supported publication. To receive new posts and support my work, consider becoming a free or paid subscriber. Pulling Up Poison Roots This summer I moved into a home with a yard and I've been overjoyed to have a piece of dirt to put my hands into. Part of it was overgrown with invasive honeysuckle. I've only relatively recently learned this plant was imported as a yard ornament that escaped gardens due to its incredibly "self-dealing" qualities, for which our local environment is not well-adapted. This type of honeysuckle releases chemicals that inhibit the growth of native plants, altering soil chemistry and microorganisms, making it hard for other species to thrive. Its berries offer little to no nutrition to wildlife and its shallow roots compete for water, sunlight and nutrients, creating bare soil vulnerable to erosion. When allowed to proliferate unchecked it will deplete resources, significantly reduce biodiversity, and negatively impact the health of the ecosystem. S
